questions.text: A 12-year-old patient presents with a history of sinusitis and now has swollen, red eyelids, pain with eye movement, and restricted extraocular motion. There is no proptosis, and CT imaging shows diffuse inflammation of the orbital tissues without abscess formation. According to Chandler's classification, what is the most likely stage of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Chandler’s Classification of Orbital Cellulitis

Stage

Description

Key Features

I - Preseptal cellulitis

Infection confined to the eyelid

Eyelid swelling, no ocular involvement

II - Orbital cellulitis

Infection spreads to the orbit

Pain with eye movement, restricted mobility, no abscess formation

III - Subperiosteal abscess

Pus collection beneath periosteum

Localized pus, proptosis, pain on movement, swelling

IV - Orbital abscess

Pus collection within the orbital tissues

Severe proptosis, potential vision loss, risk of optic nerve damage

V - Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Spread of infection to the cavernous sinus

Bilateral eye involvement, headache, cranial nerve palsies

questions.text: During a total maxillectomy for an extensive malignant tumor, the surgeon is required to remove several structures to ensure complete resection. Which of the following structures is not typically removed during this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Type

Structures Removed

Medial Maxillectomy
  • Middle turbinate
  • Inferior turbinate
  • Ethmoid sinus
  • Maxillary sinus.

Infrastructural Maxillectomy

Extends to include the upper alveolar ridge & adjoining hard palate.

Subtotal Maxillectomy

Removal of the entire Maxilla.

Total Maxillectomy

Removal of all the above structures along with the Orbital Floor.

Radical Maxillectomy

Total maxillectomy plus Orbital exenteration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction, facial swelling, and proptosis. Imaging reveals a malignancy in the Sinonasal region. According to Lederman’s classification, which of the following tumor locations is categorized as mesostructural ?

options.label: B
options.text: Extension to the respiratory part of the nasal cavity.

options.label: C
options.text: Extending to sphenoid sinus and the orbit.

questions.correct_answer: B. Extension to the respiratory part of the nasal cavity.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Lederman's classification
  • ↳ Horizontal Lines of Sebileau: These lines help delineate the categories by passing through the floors of the orbits and the antra. Vertical Lines: Extend down the medial walls of the orbit, separating the ethmoid sinuses and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses. Areas Structures Involved Prognosis Suprastructure Ethmoid Sphenoid (Option C) Frontal sinuses Olfactory area of the nose (Option A) . Poor prognosis Mesostructure Maxillary sinus Respiratory part of the nasal cavity. Better prognosis than suprastructural category. Infrastructure Alveolar process (Option D) of maxilla Better Prognosis

Prognosis

Suprastructure
  • Ethmoid

Poor prognosis

Mesostructure

Better prognosis than suprastructural category.

Infrastructure

Alveolar process (Option D) of maxilla

Better Prognosis

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction and facial swelling. Imaging shows a malignancy in the maxillary sinus. The oncologist uses Ohngren’s line to assess the prognosis. According to Ohngren’s line, which tumour location indicates a better prognosis?

A 55-year-old male carpenter presents with symptoms of persistent nasal congestion, facial swelling, and occasional nasal bleeding. He has a long history of working in the hardwood furniture industry for 30 years. CT scan reveals findings, as shown in the image. Which type of carcinoma is he most at risk for?
questions.explanation:
Osteomas
  • Frontal sinus (M/C), followed by ethmoid and maxillary sinuses.
  • Often asymptomatic; discovered incidentally on X-rays.

Fibrous Dysplasia
  • Mostly affects maxillary sinus
  • Causes Facial disfigurement, nasal obstruction, eye displacement

Ossifying Fibroma

Common in young adults & tumours are easily shellable.

Ameloblastoma (Adamantinoma)

Arises from odontogenic tissue, invades maxillary sinus.

Rare Tumors:

Inverted papilloma, Meningioma, and Hemangioma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and anosmia. A CT scan reveals an invasive mass in the nasal cavity, and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis of olfactory neuroblastoma. Which classification system is commonly used to stage olfactory neuroblastoma?
questions.explanation:
Stage A

Tumour limited to the nasal cavity.

Stage B

Tumour involving the nasal cavity and sinuses.

Stage C

Tumour extending beyond the nasal and paranasal sinuses.

Stage D

Tumor with metastasis to cervical nodes or distant sites.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a history of frontal headache, noticeable swelling on the forehead, and a recent episode of sinusitis. Physical examination reveals a soft, doughy swelling over the frontal bone, and a CT scan shows a subperiosteal abscess with associated bone erosion. What is the likely diagnosis?

Match the following conditions with their most commonly affected sinuses: Conditions Most Commonly Affected Sinus 1. Osteoma a. Maxillary sinus 2. Fibrous Dysplasia b. Ethmoid sinus 3. Chronic Rhinosinusitis with Nasal Polyps c. Frontal sinus
questions.explanation:
Condition

Definition

Most Common Site

Clinical Features

Management

Osteoma

Benign, slow-growing bony tumor affecting the paranasal sinuses.

Frontal sinus (most common), ethmoid, maxillary

Often asymptomatic; may cause sinus obstruction, mucocele formation, pressure symptoms (headache, orbital involvement).

Observation for asymptomatic cases; surgical excision for deformity, obstruction, or symptomatic cases.

Fibrous Dysplasia

Benign fibro-osseous condition where bone is replaced by fibrous tissue, causing structural weakness and deformity.

Maxillary sinus (most common), ethmoid, frontal

Facial disfigurement, nasal obstruction, eye displacement, facial pain, and swelling.

Chronic Rhinosinusitis with Nasal Polyps

Chronic inflammatory condition with nasal polyps formation.

Ethmoid sinuses (most common)

Nasal obstruction, postnasal drip, anosmia/hyposmia, facial pressure, secondary infections, erosion into orbit or brain.

Medical management (corticosteroids, antihistamines, nasal irrigations); surgery (FESS) for obstructive polyps.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a mass in the right nasal cavity. Nasal endoscopy reveals a mass arising from the lateral nasal wall with displacement of the middle turbinate. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of inverted papilloma. All of the following are true regarding inverted papilloma except?

options.label: B
options.text: It is associated with Human Papillomavirus type 6 and11.

options.label: C
options.text: The primary treatment involves endoscopic surgical excision.

options.label: D
options.text: It commonly arises from the non-olfactory mucosa.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is malignant at presentation.
questions.explanation:
Inverted Papilloma

Origin

Arises from the non-olfactory mucosa (Schneiderian membrane) of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses

Other Names

Transitional cell papilloma, Ringertz tumor, Schneiderian papilloma

Most Common Site

Lateral wall of the nose, particularly in the middle meatus.

Growth Pattern

Inward growth of hyperplastic tissue toward the stroma.

Association with HPV

Linked to Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection (particularly types 6 and 11)

Risk of Malignancy

Associated with squamous cell carcinoma in 10-15% of cases.

Symptoms

Unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds), and possible recurrent sinus infections.

Diagnosis

Endoscopic examination and biopsy for histopathological confirmation.

Treatment

Primary treatment is complete endoscopic surgical excision to minimize the risk of recurrence and malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic sinusitis presents with worsening frontal headaches, orbital pain, diplopia, and ptosis. Examination reveals limited eye movements, decreased sensation over the forehead, and mild proptosis. Superior Orbital Fissure Syndrome (SOFS) is suspected. Which cranial nerve is not involved in SOFS?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Superior Orbital Fissure Syndrome (SOFS)

Location

Superior orbital fissure (between lesser and greater wings of sphenoid bone)

Affected Structures

Cranial Nerves (CN III, IV, VI,V1)

Common Causes

Infections (sphenoid sinusitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis)

Tumors (meningioma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, metastases)

Trauma (sphenoid fractures)

Symptoms

Ophthalmoplegia (eye movement paralysis), ptosis (drooping eyelid), diplopia (double vision), frontal headache.

Potential Complications

Vision loss, impaired eye movement, facial numbness or pain

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a recent history of sinusitis. The patient has sudden-onset high fever, severe headache, eyelid swelling, and restricted eye movements. Examination reveals bilateral proptosis and sequential cranial nerve palsies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis

Orbital Cellulitis (Option A)

Onset

Sudden, high fever and headache.

Gradual, starts with eyelid swelling.

Involvement

Frequently bilateral

Typically unilateral

Cranial Nerve Involvement

Sequential palsy of CN III, IV, V1, VI

It may involve cranial nerves

Proptosis

Bilateral proptosis common

Usually unilateral proptosis

Visual Loss

More likely to cause severe visual loss

It can cause visual impairment but is less severe

Source of Infection

Broad (sinusitis, pharyngitis, ear, orbit)

Typically, it is from ethmoid sinusitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient has been experiencing nasal congestion, facial pain, and nasal discharge for one week. Examination reveals maxillary sinus tenderness and nasal obstruction. The patient reports similar episodes resolving within 10-14 days. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Causes of Chronic Sinusitis

Category

Contributing Factors

Patient Factors

Anatomic structural deformities: Obstruction of sinus ostia (e.g., deviated septum, concha bullosa, anatomical variations) (Option A)

Lifestyle factors: Smoking, snuff dipping, prolonged use of intranasal medications

Immune Deficiency

Primary: IgG deficiency, primary ciliary dyskinesia, cystic fibrosis

Acquired: HIV, prolonged steroid use, chemotherapy, immunosuppressants in organ transplant patients, leukaemia

Aspirin Sensitivity

Sensitivity to aspirin causing chronic airway inflammation. (Option D)

Environmental Factors

Aeroallergens: Allergic rhinitis, asthma, exposure to allergens (dust, pollen, moulds)

Toxins and Chemicals: Exposure to pollution, occupational chemicals, and toxic gases.

Pathogens

Bacteria (aerobic and anaerobic), fungi, mycobacteria

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with sinusitis symptoms, including severe headache, nasal congestion, and fever. Examination reveals proptosis and restricted eye movements. A CT scan shows inflammation of the ethmoid sinuses. Which of the following is not a potential complication of sinusitis with orbital involvement?
questions.explanation:
Mucocele
  • It commonly involves Frontal sinus
  • Presentation: Superomedial orbit (90% of cases) causing eye displacement forward, downward, and laterally; sometimes as cystic swelling in the forehead (10%).
  • Symptoms: Mild headache, diplopia, and proptosis.
  • Imaging: Clouded sinus with loss of scalloped outline.
  • Treatment: Frontoethmoidectomy and drainage.

Pyocele (Mucopyocele)
  • Similar to mucocele but contains pus due to infection.
  • Treatment involves endoscopic or external surgical drainage.

Osteomyelitis

Maxilla:

  • More common in infants and children due to spongy bone.
  • Symptoms: Erythema, Swelling, and Purulent discharge.

Frontal Bone:

  • Often occurs in adults & results from acute infection of frontal sinus.
  • Symptoms: Pott’s puffy tumour or an extradural, subperiosteal abscess managed with frontal sinus trephination with Lynch Howarth incision.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic patient presents with facial swelling and necrotic nasal tissue, as shown in the image & visual changes. A diagnosis of acute invasive fungal rhinosinusitis (AIFR) is suspected. Which imaging modality is most appropriate for evaluating the extent of orbital/Intracranial involvement?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

Description

A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction.

Characteristic Findings

Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI.

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment)
  • Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues.

Diagnosis
  • Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing.
  • Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features.

Imaging
  • CT: Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement.
  • CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction.
  • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain.

Treatment

Antifungal Therapy:

  • Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day.
  • Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues.
  • Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is evaluated for suspected allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS) using the Bent and Kuhn diagnostic criteria. Which of the following is not part of the Bent and Kuhn Major criteria for diagnosing AFRS?
questions.explanation:
Major Criteria (must meet all)

Minor Criteria (supportive)
  • Type I hypersensitivity (history, skin test, or in vitro testing)
  • Nasal polyposis (Option A)
  • Characteristic CT findings
  • Eosinophilic mucin without fungal invasion (Option B)
  • Positive fungal stain (Option D)
  • Asthma
  • Unilateral disease
  • Radiological bone erosion
  • Fungal cultures (Option C)
  • Serum eosinophilia
  • Charcot-Leyden crystals

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms such as a persistent headache and pain in the forehead region, indicating possible frontal sinusitis. Which imaging view is most suitable for evaluating the frontal sinuses in this situation?
questions.explanation:
X-Ray View

Position

Structures Seen

Waters’ View (Occipitomental View or Nose-Chin Position):

(Option B)

 
  • The patient's nose and chin touch the film while the X-ray beam is projected.
  • For enhanced visualisation, an open-mouth view is preferred to display the sphenoid sinus (Pierre’s View)
  • Maxillary Sinuses: Best visualised.
  • Frontal Sinuses
  • Sphenoid Sinus: Visible if the mouth is open (Pierre’s View)
  • Zygoma & Zygomatic Arch
  • Nasal Bone
  • Frontal Process of Maxilla
  • Superior Orbital Fissure
  • Infratemporal Fossa

Caldwell View (Occipitofrontal View or Nose-Forehead Position):


 

The patient’s nose and forehead touch the film & X-ray beam projected 15-20° caudally.
  • Frontal Sinuses: Best visualised.
  • Ethmoid Sinuses
  • Maxillary Sinuses
  • Frontal Process of Zygoma
  • Zygomatic Process of Frontal Bone
  • Superior Margin of Orbit and Lamina Papyracea
  • Superior Orbital Fissure

Lateral View:

(Option C)


 

The lateral side of the skull is against the film with the X-ray beam projected perpendicular from the other side.
  • Sphenoid Sinus: Anterior and posterior extent.
  • Frontal Sinus (highest sinus on lateral view)
  • Maxillary Sinus
  • Sella Turcica
  • Zygoma and Zygomatic Arch
  • Mandible: Including coronoid and condyloid processes

Submentovertical (Basal) View:

(Option D)

The X-ray beam is projected from below the chin towards the top of the head.
  • Sphenoid Sinus
  • Posterior Ethmoid Sinuses
  • Maxillary Sinuses

questions.text: A patient who underwent Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) presents with persistent nasal discharge and facial pain. During the follow-up, the surgeon considers various potential complications. Which of the following is not a common complication of FESS?
questions.explanation:
Hemorrhage
  • It is often associated with injury to the anterior ethmoidal artery or excessive middle turbinate resection.
  • Control bleeding with vasoconstrictors or bipolar diathermy; manage severe cases with topical hemostats or direct repair.

Orbital Injury (Option A)

First incision or during middle meatal antrostomy.

Orbital Hematoma

  • Associated with injury to the anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Risk if orbital fat is exposed; requires immediate management.

Optic Nerve Injury(Option B)

Possible from intra-orbital hematoma or direct damage.

CSF Leak

(Option C)
  • Risk around the vertical lamella of the cribriform plate.
  • Immediate repair is usually effective, using fat plugs, artificial materials, or fibrin glue.

Carotid Artery Injury
  • It is rare but catastrophic, especially during sphenoid surgery.
  • Immediate hemostatic resuscitation and sphenoid packing are essential; consider endovascular stenting as an alternative to direct repair.

Post Surgery Complication

Synechiae Formation: Prevented by nasal packing with Mitomycin C in the middle meatal area.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of sinusitis, including nasal obstruction, facial pain, and thick nasal discharge, persisting for the past 6 months. The patient has failed to respond to a course of antibiotics and nasal corticosteroids. What is the step in management to evaluate the extent of sinus involvement ?

A 32-year-old patient with acute sinusitis has had worsening symptoms for ten days. The patient has moderate fever, facial pain, and purulent nasal discharge. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Oral Amoxicillin with clavulanic acid
questions.explanation:
Management of Acute Sinusitis

Management Aspect

Description

Indications

Antibiotics

First-line: Oral Amoxicillin with clavulanic acid

Alternatives: Doxycycline, Levofloxacin

Duration: Typically 7-14 days

Persistent symptoms lasting >7-10 days.

Intranasal Corticosteroids

Fluticasone, Mometasone

(Reduces mucosal inflammation and improves sinus drainage)
  • Adjunctive therapy
  • Significant mucosal swelling
  • Concurrent allergic rhinitis

Saline Irrigations

Helps in thinning mucus and flushing bacteria.

Symptomatic relief and improves mucus clearance.

Topical Nasal Decongestants

Oxymetazoline, Xylometazoline
  • Provides symptomatic relief.
  • Short-term use only and avoid prolonged use to prevent rebound congestion.

Surgical Intervention

Endoscopic sinus surgery
  • For chronic or complicated sinusitis
  • Severe cases unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Complications such as orbital cellulitis

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with complaints of retro-orbital pain and occasional visual disturbances. CT imaging of the sinuses reveals a posterior ethmoid air cell extending superiorly and laterally to the sphenoid sinus, impinging on the optic nerve. What is the most likely anatomical variant responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Sinus Cell

Location

Clinical Significance

Agger Nasi Cell

Most anterior ethmoid cell, located above the lacrimal sac and below the frontal sinus.

Often involved in frontal sinus drainage issues.

Onodi Cell

Posterior ethmoid cell extending superiorly and laterally towards the sphenoid sinus, near the optic nerve

.

It may cause retro-orbital pain and visual disturbances due to proximity to the optic nerve.

Haller Cells

Infraorbital ethmoid cells extending into the floor of the orbit.

It can obstruct the maxillary sinus ostium, leading to maxillary sinusitis and occasionally orbital symptoms.




 

Frontal Recess Cell

Located in the frontal recess area.

It can affect frontal sinus drainage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of a dull headache, post-nasal drip, and retro-orbital pain. On nasal endoscopy, pus is noted draining from the superior meatus. What type of sinusitis is most likely indicated?
questions.explanation:
Sinus Type

Drainage

Common Symptoms

Posterior ethmoid sinusitis

Superior meatus

Retro-orbital pain, headache

Sphenoid sinusitis

Sphenoethmoidal recess

Occipital headache, generalised dull headache

Anterior ethmoid sinusitis

Middle meatus

Pain between eyes, nasal congestion

Maxillary sinusitis

Cheek pain, toothache

Frontal sinusitis

Frontal headache, forehead tenderness

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with facial pain, nasal congestion, and purulent nasal discharge for the past 12 days. Examination reveals tenderness over the maxillary sinuses and fever of 38°C. Which of the following is considered a major criterion for diagnosing acute sinusitis?
questions.explanation:
Major Criteria

Minor Criteria
  • Facial pain/pressure
  • Nasal obstruction/congestion
  • Purulent nasal discharge
  • Hyposmia/Anosmia
  • Fever
  • Headache
  • Dental pain
  • Ear fullness
  • Cough
  • Halitosis (bad breath)
